description: Regular expressions, the re module, patterns, groups, flags, and common recipes

cards.front: What are the 3 most common re module functions?
cards.back:
re.search(pattern, text)  — find FIRST match anywhere
re.findall(pattern, text) — find ALL matches, return list
re.sub(pattern, repl, text) — replace matches

import re
re.search(r"\d+", "age 42")   # Match: "42"
re.findall(r"\d+", "42 and 99") # ["42", "99"]
re.sub(r"\d", "X", "age 42")    # "age XX"

cards.front: Why should you always use raw strings (r"...") for regex?
cards.back:
Raw strings prevent Python from interpreting backslashes.

# WRONG — Python sees \b as backspace:
re.search("\bword\b", text)

# RIGHT — regex engine sees \b as word boundary:
re.search(r"\bword\b", text)

Without r, \n is newline, \t is tab, \b is backspace, etc.

\d — any digit (0-9)
\w — word character (letter, digit, underscore)
\s — whitespace (space, tab, newline)
.  — any character except newline

Uppercase is the opposite:
\D — non-digit
\W — non-word
\S — non-whitespace

cards.front: What do the quantifiers *, +, ?, and {n} mean?
cards.back:
*     — zero or more
+     — one or more
?     — zero or one
{3}   — exactly 3
{2,4} — between 2 and 4
{2,}  — 2 or more

\d+   matches "42", "123" but not ""
\d*   matches "42", "123", and ""

cards.front: How do groups work in regex?
cards.back:
Parentheses () capture parts of the match.

match = re.search(r"(\d{4})-(\d{2})-(\d{2})", "2024-01-15")
match.group()   # "2024-01-15" (entire match)
match.group(1)  # "2024" (first group)
match.group(2)  # "01"

Named groups: (?P<year>\d{4})
match.group("year")  # "2024"

cards.front: What is the difference between greedy and lazy matching?
cards.back: Greedy (default) — matches as MUCH as possible Lazy (add ?) — matches as LITTLE as possible text = "bold and more" re.search(r".*", text).group() # "bold and more" — greedy re.search(r".*?", text).group() # "bold" — lazy

^ — start of string
$ — end of string
\b — word boundary

re.match(r"^\d+$", "12345")  # Match (only digits)
re.match(r"^\d+$", "123abc") # No match

re.findall(r"\bcat\b", "the cat sat on the catalog")
# ["cat"] — does NOT match "cat" inside "catalog"

cards.front: What is the common mistake when search() returns None?
cards.back:
Calling .group() on None crashes.

# WRONG:
result = re.search(r"\d+", "no numbers").group()  # AttributeError!

# RIGHT:
match = re.search(r"\d+", "no numbers")
if match:
    result = match.group()

Always check if search() returned None before using .group().
